
Tags: #ml 

------------------------------------------
R-squared and adjusted R-squared are both measures of how well a regression model fits the data. R-squared is the proportion of the variation in the dependent variable that is explained by the independent variables. Adjusted R-squared is similar to R-squared, but it takes into account the number of independent variables in the model.

Both R-squared and adjusted R-squared are related to simple linear regression, which is a type of regression model that uses one independent variable to predict the value of a dependent variable. R-squared and adjusted R-squared can be used to evaluate the fit of a simple linear regression model.

The significance of R-squared and adjusted R-squared is that they can be used to determine how well a regression model fits the data. A high R-squared or adjusted R-squared value indicates that the model fits the data well. A low R-squared or adjusted R-squared value indicates that the model does not fit the data well.

Here are some additional details about R-squared and adjusted R-squared:

-   R-squared is calculated as the square of the correlation coefficient between the dependent variable and the independent variables.
-   Adjusted R-squared is calculated as R-squared minus the number of independent variables in the model divided by the degrees of freedom.
-   A high R-squared or adjusted R-squared value indicates that the model fits the data well.
-   A low R-squared or adjusted R-squared value indicates that the model does not fit the data well.

R-squared and adjusted R-squared are important measures of the fit of a regression model. They can be used to evaluate the fit of a model and to determine whether the model is useful for making predictions.
